wiki.content: "Drops of Jupiter (Tell Me)" is an alternative rock song by California rock band Train on their second album Drops of Jupiter (2001). It was their first single from the album, and hit the top 5 of the Billboard Hot 100, peaking at number 5 on the chart. The song has spent over 100 weeks on the Adult Contemporary charts, and is still charting on the Recurrents chart. Although the song was released years before digital download became commonplace, the song has sold over 100,000 downloads (giving it a Gold certification by the RIAA), and hit the top 50 of the Digital Downloads charts five years after its release. The song won 2 Grammy Awards for "Best Rock Song" and "Best Instrumental Arrangement Accompanying Vocalist(s)". Due to its unique and enigmatic lyrics, the meaning of song has been the subject of speculation since its release. Lead singer Pat Monahan has stated that the song was inspired by the death of his mother, and that the opening lines came to him in a dream. The song, which started as a song about his mother, has evolved into a love song, according to Monahan in 2006. On March 29, 2005, Judy Collins release a cover version of this song on her Portrait of an American Girl album. As of 2008 K!d B. has released his cover version which is said to be on his album A K!d Like B. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License and may also be available under the GNU FDL.

track.name: Drops of Jupiter
comments: This is the song any girl would love their significant other to dedicate to them.
Just saw them in concert with Michael Franti and Spearhead!  BOTH WERE OUTSTANDING, OUTSTANDING, OUTSTANDING! They really "get it"!
Not even that old of a track yet, but still a classic in my book :)
one of the few I actually like a lot from them the rest of there stuff is ok to me
You miss me while you're looking for yourself out there...
good song from the album Drops Of Jupiter
This will always be my favourite Train song
Pretty much the anthem of the early 2000s for me.
best Train song before, best Train song now, best Train song for all eternity
